text: Come and see the works of God: he is terrible in his doing toward the children of men.
text_kjv: Come and see the works of God: he is terrible in his doing toward the children of men.
text_niv: Come and see what God has done,how awesome his works in man’s behalf!
text_esv: Come and see what God has done: he is awesome in his deeds toward the children of man.
text_nlt: Come and see what our God has done,what awesome miracles he performs for people!
text_msg: Take a good look at God's wonders—they'll take your breath away.
text_nasb: Come and see the works of God, [Who is] awesome in [His] deeds toward the sons of men.
context: Psalm 66 is a hymn of thanksgiving, likely composed for corporate worship in the temple after a national deliverance. The exact historical event behind the psalm is debated, but possibilities include deliverance from military defeat, famine, or plague. The phrase 'children of men' (בְּנֵי אָדָם, bə·nê ā·ḏām) is a common Hebrew expression denoting humanity in general, not just a specific group. The setting would have been a time of communal celebration, with offerings and praise directed towards God for his powerful intervention. Understanding the temple setting and the communal nature of the psalm is crucial for interpreting verse 5. Temple worship involved visual elements, such as sacrifices, processions, and the physical structure itself, designed to inspire awe and reverence. The call to 'come and see' (לְכוּ וּרְאוּ, lə·ḵū ū·rə·’ū) implies a direct invitation to witness tangible evidence of God's power. The psalm as a whole transitions from a general call to praise to a more specific recounting of God's saving acts, culminating in a personal expression of gratitude from the psalmist. It is believed by many scholars that the psalm may have been used during the Feast of Tabernacles or another major pilgrimage festival. These festivals served as powerful reminders of God's faithfulness throughout Israel's history, reinforcing their covenant relationship with Him. The use of parallelism and repetition, common in Hebrew poetry, would have enhanced the psalm's impact during its recitation in the temple.
meaning: Theologically, Psalm 66:5 presents a profound paradox: God's actions are both awe-inspiring and 'terrible' (נוֹרָא, nō·rā). The word 'terrible' should not be understood in a solely negative sense. In this context, 'terrible' signifies the immense power, majesty, and even destructive capacity of God when he acts on behalf of his people. It speaks to the overwhelming nature of his interventions, which surpass human comprehension. God's 'doing' (עֲלִילָה, ‘ă·lî·lāh) towards humanity highlights his active involvement in the world. He is not a passive observer but an active agent who shapes history and responds to the needs of his people. The verse emphasizes the vast difference between the divine and the human. God's power is so great that it evokes both awe and fear, challenging human notions of control and self-sufficiency. The phrase 'children of men' further underscores the universal scope of God's actions. He is not merely concerned with a select few but with all of humanity. This verse serves as a reminder of the importance of reverence and humility in the presence of God. It calls for a recognition of his supreme authority and an acceptance of his will, even when it is difficult to understand. The 'terrible' nature of God's actions also highlights the seriousness of sin and the consequences of disobedience. God's wrath is not arbitrary but a righteous response to injustice and rebellion. Therefore, the verse is a call to repentance and a plea for God's mercy.
application: Psalm 66:5 challenges us to actively seek and recognize God's work in our lives and the world around us. 'Come and see' is an invitation to be observant, to look beyond the surface, and to discern the hand of God in both the good and the challenging circumstances we face. In a world often characterized by uncertainty and chaos, this verse offers a powerful reminder that God is still active and in control. Acknowledge that God's ways are often beyond our understanding. Instead of demanding explanations for every difficulty, trust in his wisdom and sovereignty. Embrace the 'terrible' aspects of God, not in fear, but in reverence and awe. Recognize that his power is often manifested in ways that challenge our comfort and complacency. Seek to understand God's justice and righteousness, even when it requires facing difficult truths about ourselves and the world. This means confronting sin and injustice, both personally and corporately. Apply this verse practically by journaling about instances where you have witnessed God's power, both in miraculous interventions and in subtle blessings. Share these experiences with others to encourage their faith. Volunteer your time and resources to organizations that are working to alleviate suffering and promote justice, recognizing that you are participating in God's work in the world. Develop a daily practice of prayer and meditation to cultivate a deeper awareness of God's presence in your life. Intentionally look for opportunities to praise and thank God for his faithfulness and power. Remember that true worship involves both adoration and obedience. Allow God's 'terrible' power to inspire you to live a life of humility, service, and devotion. This requires a willingness to surrender your will to his and to trust in his plan, even when it is unclear.
prayer: Sovereign God, we come before you humbled by your power and majesty. We confess that we often fail to recognize your hand in our lives and in the world. Open our eyes to see your works, both the gentle blessings and the awe-inspiring interventions. Forgive us for our lack of reverence and our tendency to question your ways. Help us to embrace the 'terrible' aspects of your nature, not in fear, but in a spirit of awe and submission. Grant us the wisdom to understand your justice and the courage to live according to your will. May your Spirit guide us to discern your purposes in every situation and to respond with faith and obedience. Thank you for your active involvement in our lives and for your unwavering love. Help us to trust you more fully, knowing that you are always working for our good. In Jesus' name, Amen.

faqs.answer: The word 'terrible' (nō·rā) conveys the immense power and awe-inspiring nature of God's actions. It's not strictly negative but highlights the overwhelming character of his interventions, emphasizing his majesty and potential for both creation and destruction. It speaks to a reverence for the divine beyond human comprehension.
faqs.question: Q1 about this verse: Why does the verse use the word 'terrible' when describing God's actions?

faqs.answer: The 'terrible' aspect of God's actions directly correlates with the fear of the Lord. This 'fear' isn't abject terror, but a profound reverence and respect for God's power, wisdom, and holiness. It acknowledges His supreme authority and motivates obedience and humility.
faqs.question: Q2: How does this verse relate to the concept of the fear of the Lord?

faqs.answer: 'Come and see' today means actively seeking evidence of God's presence and power in our lives and the world. This includes observing answered prayers, acts of kindness and justice, and even recognizing God's hand in difficult circumstances. It's a call to attentiveness and discernment.
faqs.question: Q3: What does it mean to 'come and see' the works of God in a modern context?

faqs.answer: God's love and compassion are perfectly balanced with his justice and power. His 'terrible' actions often stem from his love, as He confronts evil and protects his people. Divine justice, though sometimes severe, ultimately aims at restoration and redemption, guided by love.
faqs.question: Q4: How can we reconcile the 'terrible' nature of God with His love and compassion?

faqs.answer: No, this verse doesn't imply arbitrariness. While God's ways may surpass our understanding, his actions are always rooted in his character and purpose, which are revealed through Scripture. We can trust that He is consistent with His promises and faithful to His covenant.
faqs.question: Q5: Is this verse suggesting God is arbitrary or unpredictable in his actions?
